3.24.20  1:22 am   Why is there something rather than nothing?

      hotewig briefly covers this topic, as an unknown entity wishes to be something, go somewhere, do something, for things to change, and to invent time and space. But those concepts didn't even exist before the universe started. Those concepts only work within the framework of the universe and everything not existing all at once (separated by time). Somehow, it devised the concept of "change" in a sea of  where the concept of change didn't even exist. In fact, nothing would have been able to devise the concept of change, as thinking requires change in the form of movement of electricity across neurons, and in the energy expended thereof.

     There was a point in the nothingness that was perturbed somehow, and this first change led to a cascade. What perturbed nothingness?

      Did nothingness not-exist forever which is so long that something would've happened?

     Is this the consequence of eternity?
